prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J084933.4+021443 OH+ and CO(9-8)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is an observation of J084933.4+021443 in the OH+ 1033 GHz line and CO(9-8). Three correlator bands are defined in one baseband, 2 centred on the two lines, and one on the continuum red of the OH+ line; this latter band will also cover any red wing of the OH+ line. One pointing is sufficient.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We centre two overlapping correlator bands on the OH+ 1033 GHz line and CO(9-8). A 3rd correlator band is put on the continuum on the red side of the OH+ line. This will also cover any extended red line wing in the OH+ line. For the typical expected line widths of a few hundred km/s, the spectral resolution is easily enough.
We have taken our source morphologies from our SMA 340 GHz images (Bussmann et a., 2013, ApJ, 779, 25, Fig. 2). Our typical source sizes are 1-2", except J114637.9-001132, which is about 4".

The expected continuum flux density is 48 mJy and this is contained in about 5 beams, as shown in our SMA data (Bussmann et al., 2013, ApJ, 779, 25, Fig. 2). So we get about 10 mJy/beam. The smallest expected absorption line flux is 25% of this. We aim to detect this weakest line at 5sigma (rms 0.5 mJy) at a velocity resolution of 50 km/s, which is sufficient.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J085358.9+015537 OH+ and CO(9-8)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The is an observation of J085358.9+015537 in the OH+ 1033 GHz line and CO(9-8). Three correlator bands are defined in one baseband, 2 centred on the two lines, and one on the continuum red of the OH+ line; this latter band will also cover any red wing of the OH+ line. One pointing is sufficient.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We centre two overlapping correlator bands on the OH+ 1033 GHz line and on CO(9-8). A third correlator band is put on the continuum on the red side of the OH+ line. This band will also cover any very redshifted linewing from the OH+ line. Since the linewidths of our targets are a few 100 km/s the spectral resolution is easily sufficient.
We have taken our source sizes from our 340 GHz SMA imaging (Bussmann et al., 2013, ApJ, 779, 25, Fig 2). Typical source sizes are 1-2", except J114637.9-001132, which is about 4".

The measured continuum flux density is about 61 mJy and this is contained in about 6 beams, as shown by our SMA imaging (Bussmann et al., 2013, ApJ, 2013, 779, 25, Fig 2), so we get about 10 mJy/beam. The weakest expected absorption line is 25% of this and we need to detect this weakest line at 5sigma (rms 0.5 mJy) at a velocity resolution of 50 km/s which is sufficient.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J090302.9-014127 OH+ and CO(9-8)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is an observation of J090302.9-014127 in the OH+ 1033 GHz line and CO(9-8). Three correlator bands are defined in one baseband, 2 centred on the two lines, and one on the continuum red of the OH+ line; this latter band will also cover any red wing of the OH+ line. One pointing is sufficient.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We centre two overlapping correlator bands on the OH+ 1033 GHz line and CO(9-8). A third correlator band is put on the continuum on the red side of the OH+ line. This band will also detect any very redshifted OH+ linewing emission, if present. Since the linewidths of our targets are a few 100 km/s, the velocity resolution is easily sufficient.
We have taken our source sizes from our 340 GHz SMA imaging (Bussmann et al., 2013, ApJ, 779, 25, Fig 2). Typical source sizes are 1-2" except J114637.9-001132 which is about 4".

The expected total continuum flux is about 51 mJy and this is contained in about 5 beams, as shown by our SMA data (Bussmann et al., 2013, ApJ, 779, 25, Fig 2), so we will get about 10 mJy/beam. The smallest expected absorption line flux is about 25% of this. We aim to detect this weakest line at 5sigma (rms = 0.5 mJy) at a velocity resolution of 50 km/s, which is sufficient.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J021830.5-053124 OH+ and CO(9-8)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The is an observation of J021830.5-053124 in the OH+ 1033 GHz line and CO(9-8). Three correlator bands are defined in one baseband, 2 centred on the two lines, and one on the continuum red of the OH+ line; this latter band will also cover any red wing of the OH+ line. One pointing is sufficient.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We put 2 overlapping correlator bands on the OH+ 1033 GHz line and on CO(9-8). A third correlator band is put on the continuum on the red side of the OH+ line. This band will also detect any very redshifted OH+ linewing emission, if present. Given the typical linewidths of our targets of a few 100 km/s, the spectral resolution is easily enough.
We have taken our source sizes from our 340 GHz SMA imaging (Bussmann et al., 2013, ApJ, 779, 25, Fig 2). Typical source sizes are 1-2", except J114637.9-001132 which is about 4".

The total continuum flux density is about 56 mJy and this is contained in about 7 beams, based on our SMA imaging (Bussmann et al, 2013, ApJ, 779, 25, Fig 2). so we expect about 8 mJy/beam. The weakest expected absorption line is about 25% of the continuum and we aim to detect this weakest line at 5 sigma (rms = 0.4 mJy) at a velocity resolution of 50 km/s which is sufficient.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J114637.9-001132 OH+ and CO(9-8)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is an observation of J114637.9-001132 in the OH+ 1033 GHz line and CO(9-8). Three correlator bands are defined in one baseband, 2 centred on the two lines, and one on the continuum red of the OH+ line; this latter band will also cover any red wing of the OH+ line. One pointing is sufficient.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We centre two correlator bands on the OH+ 1033 GHz line and CO(9-8). We put a third correlator band on the continuum on the red side of the OH+ line. This band will also detect any very redshifted linewing OH+ emission, if present. Given the line widths of a few 100 km/s of our targets, the spectral resolution is easily enough.
We have taken our source sizes from our 340 GHz SMA imaging (Bussmann et al., 2013, ApJ, 779, 25, Fig 2). The size of this object is about 4".

The total expected continuum flux density is about 79 mJy and this is contained in about 12 beams, based on our SMA imaging (Bussmann et al., ApJ, 779, 25, Fig 2), so we expect on average about 7 mJy/beam. The weakest expected line is about 25% of this and we need to detect this weakest feature at 5 sigma (rms = 0.35 mJy) at a velocity resolution of 50 km/s which is sufficient.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to establish the use of the OH+ lines as a robust outflow tracer in luminous high-z galaxies. The OH+ line displays pronounced P-cygni profiles in local ULIRGs, where the line is ubiquitous and about half as bright as CO lines, and as such should be an ideal outflow probe of high-z galaxies for ALMA. We target 5 gravitationally lensed high-z ULIRGs (3 at z=2-2.5, 2 at z=3-3.5), with spectroscopic redshifts and good magnification models, to test this method. We use a setup combining OH+ with the nearby CO(9-8) line, which provides a direct measurement of the velocity of any OH+ emission or absorption with respect to the bulk gas. We will measure outflow velocities as a function of position over the galaxies, pinpoint the origin of the outflow and assess the relation between outflow velocity infrared luminosity and surface brightness. Bright detections will be followed up at high resolution in a future cycle.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
